captions.text:
JAMES GRIME: One of the reasons
we're fascinated by

primes is that they are quite
weird in the way they behave.

On one hand, they kind
of feel random.

They are turning up all
over the place.

Sometimes you have these long
gaps between primes.

And then suddenly-- like buses,
you get a couple of
primes turn up at once.

On the other hand, there are
things that we can predict

about primes and when they're
going to turn up, which is

slightly unexpected that
you can do that.
They're not completely random.

One of the first things I want
to show you, then, is a nice
easy thing.

So everyone can do
this at home.

We're going to write the numbers
in a square spiral.
Start with 1 in the middle.
Then you write 2.
But you go around it--

4, 5, 6, 7, 8-- do you see
the pattern, then?
It's a square spiral.
it's called an Ulam spiral--

Stanislaw Ulam, he was a
Polish mathematician.

And he left Poland just
before World War II,
and he went to America.

And he worked on the
Manhattan Project.

After World War II, he
went into academia.

The story of this spiral is,
he sat in a very boring
lecture in academia.
It was in 1963.

And so he's obviously a fan
of Vi Hart or someone.

He sat there doodling during
this boring lecture.

And he's writing out
the numbers.

The next thing he
did was start to
circle the prime numbers.
So let's do that.

2 is a prime, and then 3, and
then 5, and 7, and 11, 13, not

40, 41, 43, is prime,
and so on.

And he noticed, and maybe you
can see, these stripes, the

prime numbers seem to be lining
up on diagonal lines.

And if you do this larger, if
you do more and more numbers,

and you write them out
in a spiral, that
tends to be the case.
I've got one here.
This is a big Ulam spiral.

I think this is something
huge.

I think this is like
200 by 200.

And so there's 40,000 numbers
or something here.

Can you see, though, can
you see the stripes?

There's definitely some
stripes here,
these diagonal lines.

So prime numbers seem to be
lying on diagonal lines.

Or to put it another way, some
diagonal lines have lots of

primes, and some diagonal
lines don't
have lots of primes.

So you can see the stripes
start to form.

BRADY HARAN: Are they
continuous stripes?

They look a bit broken
up to me.

JAMES GRIME: Yeah, they are
not continuous stripes.

But they have more than average
number of primes.

So these stripes might be a good
place to look for more

primes, bigger primes,
new primes.

One thing people might say is,
oh, we're just seeing patterns
in randomness.

Those aren't really
stripes at all.
It's just the human brain.

See, if you compare it
with randomness--

this, the same size, these
are random numbers.

And you can see, it's pretty
much white noise.

I can't really see any
pattern in this.

You can see that
that is random.

And you can see that that
is something more
than just being random.

BRADY HARAN: These ginormous
primes that get found, are
they found on diagonals?

Like this largest prime known,
was that on diagonal?

JAMES GRIME: The largest prime
known was a Mersenne prime,

which is of the type 2 to
the power n minus 1.

It's one less than a power of 2,
which is a way to look for
large primes.

It's computationally kind
of easier to do.

Perhaps it's not the most
fruitful way because they are
quite rare, Mersenne primes.

This might be another way to
do it because this stripe

here, this diagonal,
has an equation.

This equation is for this one
here, this half line, which

means it starts at three and
goes off to infinity.

The equation for that is 4x
squared minus 2x plus 1.
Let me just try it.
Let's do the first one here.

So if x is equal to
1, yeah, that's 3.

If we tried the next one here,
x equals 2, it's 13.
And this one here, that's 31.

And well, best do one more, just
to show you what comes
next, 56 plus 57--
is that a prime number, Brady?

BRADY HARAN: 57 is not
a prime number.

JAMES GRIME: It's not
a prime number.

So the next one isn't a prime
number, but 57 would be the
next number on that line.

BRADY HARAN: So that's one of
the breaks in our dotted line?

JAMES GRIME: Yeah, so all these
lines, the, in fact,

horizontal lines, vertical
lines, and diagonal lines,
they are all like this.

All the quadratic equations
are like that.

So what we're saying is, some
quadratic equations have more
primes on them than others.

And that's the conjecture,
actually.
That hasn't been proved.
But that is the conjecture.
It seems to be the case.

So there are lines here that
have seven times as many
primes as other lines.

And the best we've found is a
diagonal line that has 12

times as many primes
as the average.

BRADY HARAN: Cool, has
that line got a name?

JAMES GRIME: I can write
it out for you.
I think I had it somewhere.

BRADY HARAN: Yeah, I'd love
to know what that line is.
The golden line.

JAMES GRIME: This golden line
that Brady has now decided to

call it, it's a quadratic
equation.

It starts off quite
simply again.

But the number you add
on is not plus one.
It's plus something huge.

This square spiral is called
Ulam's spiral.

But there's one that
I like even more.
It's called a Sack's spiral.
And it works like this.

You write the square
number in a line.

The square numbers are 1, 4,
yeah, that is 2 squared, 3

squared is 9, 16,
25, and so on.

So you write the square
numbers in a line.

Then I connect them with what
is called an Archimedean
spiral like that.

And then I would the other
numbers on that spiral and
evenly space it.

And if you mark off the primes
for that, I've got this

already sorted out for you, this
is the picture you get.

And you can see the relations,
you can see the pattern, even
more strikingly, I think.
Look at these curves.
These are the primes.

BRADY HARAN: And obviously,
you'll never get a prime along

there because those
are the squares.

JAMES GRIME: Those are your
squares, that big gap there is
the squares.

So it looks like we have
formulas, equations--

some formulas, anyway, that have
more primes than others.

So if we can understand these
formulas that contain these

rich number of primes, then it
would help us solve important

conjectures in mathematics
such as the Goldbach

conjecture and the twin
prime conjecture.

So prime numbers are not as
random as you might think of.

There are equations to help
us find prime numbers.

And now I want to show you some
equations that help you
find prime numbers.

BRADY HARAN: So we'll have more
about ways to search for

prime numbers coming really soon
from this interview with
James Grime--

unless you're watching this in
the future, in which case this

stuff might already
be on YouTube.
But you get the idea.

But, I have a bit of a
confession to make.

I've actually recorded some
stuff about the spirals and
prime numbers before--

not with James Grime, but
with James Clewett.

And I kind of half forgot about
it and never got around
to editing it.

This was, like, a year
and a half ago.

I went back and had a look,
and it was actually really
interesting.

So I've turned that into
a video as well.

Now you can wait for that turn
up in your subscriptions, in

the next few days, or if you
can't wait, you can go and
have a look at it now.
I've made the links available.

The video's already up, so
go ahead and have a look.
Thanks for watching.

Plenty more videos, both of
stuff I've recorded, some of

it quite a while ago, it turns
out, and stuff we've
still got to record.

Really exciting stuff coming
soon on "Numberphile," so make
sure you've subscribed.

comments.author: Nintendo101maniac

comments.text:
+Nintendo101maniac That doesn't work for most numbers though... Not just 
multiples of 4. (3^2)+1 = 10, (5^2)+1 = 26, (7^2)+1 = 50 and so on. Now if 
you are only talking about x being an even number and even x not being 
divisible by 4, then your formula already stops working at 18, since 18^2+1 
= 325. Also it does work for 16 though, since 257 is a prime so the theory 
about it not working for multiples of 4 is also wrong. You did say "most 
multiples of 4" though but Your formula just gets a prime for a few even 
numbers, where most are not divisible by 4 (which means around every other 
even number doesn't give you a prime). I understand your way of thinking 
but the formula only rarely works and is pretty useless
comments.author: coolkid17657

comments.text:
+Nintendo101maniac If you want to multiply by something and then add 1 or 
some other prime to it, there are numbers called the primorials (products 
of the first prime factors)2*3 = 6
2*3*5 = 30
2*3*5*7 = 210


Even still, it's not very effective.


210 * 17 + 19 (this ensures it's not divisible by 2, 3, 5, 7, 17, or 19)


is 3589. 3589 is 37 * 97 -.-

210 * 11 + 13 = 2323, that number is 101 * 23


So primes are tough to find...

Sixth primorial = 2*3*5*7*11*13 = 30030


Try 30030 * 23 + 29 = 690719; FINALLY that one is prime.

Check the numbers which are adjacent to highly composite numbers, since 
those numbers can't be divisible by any factors of the very composite ones. 
The highly composite number 60 is between two primes, as is 240.
comments.author: Cooper Gates

comments.text:
+Nintendo101maniac
Unfortunately, simple formulas like that rarely work. For instance, here's 
the result of carrying your formula out to x = 20. You don't have to worry 
about the stuff at the beginning, that's just how I checked whether a 
number is prime or not. In short, it shows x, followed by x^2+1, followed 
by True if it's prime or False if it's not prime. As you can see, the prime 
numbers quickly get pretty sparse!

>>> def is_prime(n):
...   max = math.ceil(math.sqrt(n))
...   if n <= 1:
...     return False
...   if n % 2 == 0:
...     return n == 2
...   for i in range(3, max + 1, 2):
...     if n % i == 0:
...       return False
...   return True
... 
>>> for n in range(0, 21):
...   print(str(n) + " - " + str(int(math.pow(n, 2) + 1)) + ": " + 
str(is_prime(math.pow(n, 2) + 1)))
... 
0 - 1: False
1 - 2: True
2 - 5: True
3 - 10: False
4 - 17: True
5 - 26: False
6 - 37: True
7 - 50: False
8 - 65: False
9 - 82: False
10 - 101: True
11 - 122: False
12 - 145: False
13 - 170: False
14 - 197: True
15 - 226: False
16 - 257: True
17 - 290: False
18 - 325: False
19 - 362: False
20 - 401: True

comments.author: Nintendo101maniac

comments.text:
+Nintendo101maniac If x is an odd number, x^2+1 isn't prime. Let x=2n+1 
with n in the naturals, x^2+1=(2n+1)^2+1=4n^2+4n+1+1=2(2n^2+2n+1).
comments.author: Ste Rose

comments.text:
+Nintendo101maniac Primes are so plentiful in the low values that it easy 
to believe that you found a pattern, but as you increase the number the 
pattern begins to fall apart.
comments.author: thediltarget

comments.text:
+Nintendo101maniac the solution for any odd number definitely isn't a 
prime, because any odd number squared is an odd number, so adding or 
subtracting 1 results in an even number. obviously even numbers are not 
prime.
comments.author: Jack Neubecker

comments.text:
You can't generate primes just by taking even integers and squaring and 
adding 1. For example, look at Fermat numbers. Every number of the form 
2^(2^n) + 1 is one more than a square, because 2^(2^n-1) squared gives us 
2^(2^n). For n = 5 through 32, these numbers are composite, and most 
mathematicians believe that all Fermat numbers for n > 4 are composite 
(although we don't actually know). For n = 0 through 4, they are prime.
comments.author: thebombzen

comments.text:
It is a good idea but to create a principle, there needs to be logic behind 
it. What you're suggesting is as random as pulling a cat out of a bag of 
ferrets. Ulam's spiral works but only for certain sections of certain arms 
of it, many of which are unconnected. It would be interesting however to 
see if prime numbers could be connected to Pascal's triangle or other 
shapes in maths.

comments.text:
So when you write out the spiral you get alternating diagonals of even and 
odd numbers. The primes will fall along the odd bands and never the even 
bands except the number 2. You get stripes along the diagonals because of 
the high density of primes that fall among the lower integers. I imagine 
the stripes dissipate as the square grows much larger. Every 6th number 
after 3 (9,15,21,27) " kills " a stripe. I don't really understand why 
primes falling along the bands of these odd numbers is such a phenomenon. 
Please enlighten me.﻿

comments.text:
There is nothing unusual with this. Primes are odd numbers (not even) or 
even better to say, all primes are numbers that ends with either 1 or 5 in 
the base 6. When you place them in this spiral you will get a more likely 
to have 2 primes as checker-board neighbors then vertical/horizontal 
neighbors. Why that? well think for yourself. It's trivial if you think 
about it. Put any series of numbers that have same properties like i told, 
as the primes and you'll get the same results.﻿

comments.author: theworldofwonder

comments.text:
The Primes MUST be on a diagonal, while NOT EVERY number on any diagonal is 
a Prime.  An argument can be made from alternating EVEN and ODD numbers 
that "turning the CORNER" of the spiral maintaing the position, or 
membeship, on a diagonal.

Said another way *ALL ADJACENT ODDS* must have *Adjacent Diagonal* 
relationships.  ODDS may never have ADJACENT Horizontal or Vertial odds.﻿

comments.author: славянин

comments.text:
Arrogantly I called this "mySpiral" when I found about this on my own some 
15 years ago. There is another property about these stripes that I found, 
this formula is more broad than a quadratic but it safe to say that all 
Prime numbers are of the form 6xn+1 or 6xn-1 or even more adventurous as 
2x3xn+1 or 2x3xn-1. Try them out. For the jumpy people keep in mind that 
this doesn't mean "if and only if". Back to the main point, these offsets 
-1, +1 is what seems to be the "fabric" of the prime number set where a 
number cannot be written (partially and perhaps recursively in some way) in 
terms of this Holy Trinity "1,2,3".﻿

things we can see and touch and make but not for say explaining what 
Gravity exactly is and why it works. Hopefully, someone is working a better

comments.text:
If we assume that (some quadratic eq) has more primes than (some other 
quadratic equation) and let S be the set of all primes in the quadratic 
equation with more and let L be the set of all primes in the quadratic 
equation with less, then we would see that S > L. 

However, as we know the primes are infinite and each quadratic equation is 
also infinite, we would get (Infiniti) > (infiniti) which is false. Thus, 
it is not true that One quadratic has has more primes than another.


Does this work?﻿

comments.text:
So the Ultimate Conjecture would be that NO ONE EQUATION per se HAS ALL THE 
PRIMES? That Ulam's Spiral is an infinite? or finite set of Equations (are 
they all Quadratic? All Polynomial? . All repetions of one standard line 
fragment differing only by its slope and its actual mapped out location on 
Ulam's Spiral (that each & every line fragment on Ulam's Spiral differs 
only by its m value and length of its fragment part from the entire 
line: Y=mx+b...?) that contain all the Primes, but that each Equation or 
its Formula contains only a "limited number of Primes?"? That as One goes 
further expanding Ulam's Spiral ever outward to vast distances in all 
directions: that each Equation's fragment though still containing only a 
limited number of Primes: nevertheless approaches infinity if Ulam's Siral 
is extended far enough out, but that It Does nevertheless increase that 
limited number of Primes, but never reaches  it for each and every equation 
out there From Here To Infinity? Or that on the average for all equations: 
only a CERTAIN MINIMUM AND CERTAIN MAXIMUM  is attainable for how many 
primes for each line segment, each formula?  Is the minimum AT LEAST 2 
Primes? or some higher number like 100? According to Euclid, only 2 points 
are needed to establish a line: must every line fragment in Ulam's Spiral 
give out at least 2 primes? But that some line way out there in Ulam's 
extended Spiral a certain Diagonal will give out 100 Primes but no more? 
Then another line, say, 2 light years away in actual further extension of 
the actual Ulam Spiral on this Video will then give 1000 Primes but no 
more? Or that in the forever expansion of Ulam's Spiral: all limited Primes 
will stay around 2 to 3 to 4, etc, but never reach any bigger 
number? from  what are the greatest number possible?﻿

comments.author: stallmanswife

comments.text:
I wouldn't say that Mersenne primes are rare. They are spaced further apart 
than primes in terms of sequence. In fact, since Mersenne primes are 
generated by 2^p - 1, where p is prime (NB: 2^p - 1 prime iff p prime), the 
prime numbers can be put into a 1 - 1 correspondence with the Mersenne 
primes, so we can say there are equally as many Mersenne primes as there 
are primes.﻿

definitely seeing math! Math isn't the representation of patterns with 
Arabic numerals--it's those patterns themselves :)
